1

Inadequate processes for maintaining ample Group level insurance coverage 

Group insurance for all verticals is centrally managed by the Administration Specialist. Group insurance coverage includes Property All Risk, General Liability, Marine, Management Liability, Political Risk and Fidelity Guarantee.
We noted that the process for adding or removing businesses and locations under the Group's various insurance policies lacks clear documentation and defined procedures. Currently, Administration Specialist is intimated by Group Legal Department or the Administration Department of the respective Country on an ad hoc basis regarding the new entities / businesses or closures. 
This increases the risk of gaps in coverage or inadvertent omissions, potentially leaving critical assets uninsured or incurring unnecessary costs for redundant coverage.

Level 1

The Admin department should:
1) Develop Standard Operating Procedures for the timely addition or removal of businesses and locations from insurance policies and Include steps for initiating, reviewing, and approving changes in coverage.
2) Assign clear accountability to specific roles across verticals for ensuring accurate and timely updates to insurance policies.
3) Implement a monitoring mechanism of insured assets and locations to ensure that the insurance policy aligns with current operational requirements and maintain an up-to-date register of insured locations and assets.

While this gap exists, the involvement of multiple stakeholders—such as Retail Store Operations, Legal, Local Administration, Store/Brand Managers, and external mall entities— reduce the likelihood of gaps due to the vested interest of all parties as insurance documentation is always required for compliance for external stakeholders. 

Namely, there are several operational roadblocks help mitigate this risk such as:

• New stores cannot commence operations without proof of insurance, which is mandatory for all malls regionwide.
• Minor works clearance is not given by any mall without proof of any valid certificate.
• Regulatory requirements by governing bodies require proof of insurance
• Joint Ventures require proof of insurance for warehouses and rented premises, etc...

Nevertheless, we fully recognize the importance of having clear, documented procedures to improve efficiency and accountability. 

Service Request and Incident Management Portal will be created for requests related to insurance related service requests and incident management following loss. This will help to:

• Streamline processes for incident reporting and claims management.
• Improve tracking, accountability, and transparency for all involved parties.

Also, clearly define roles, ownership of responsibilites, and procedural requirements will be defined for all stakeholders. (Applicable Groupwide)

Overdue

9

Absence of Money Insurance coverage across the Group

The Group currently lacks an insurance policy to cover risks associated with the loss of money during transit, on-premises, or in safes due to any unforeseen events. This exposes the company to potential financial losses in scenarios where cash is targeted.
It is pertinent to note that there is a third party cash collection and deposit service provider that covers the risk of cash in transit while in their custody for up to 500K USD for store locations in UAE, KSA, Kuwait, Bahrain and Qatar. India also uses a third party collection service. 
However, this control is not present in Jordan, Oman and Egypt Duty free shops and excludes cash maintained in office safes. 

Level 2

Insurance team to calculate the financial exposure for the uncovered markets and locations and present the cost of insurance as part of the upcoming  insurance coverage renewal exercise.

We note your concern regarding the absence of a standalone policy covering potential loss of money during transit, on-premises, or in safes. Below are key factors that mitigate this concern:

• Employees do not carry cash for commercial purposes.
• Our security provider offers full risk transfer by transporting store cash in armoured vehicles, insuring up to USD 500,000 for loss while in their custody.
• Petty cash transfers, while not covered under current provisions, represent a relatively small exposure involving immaterial amounts.
• Cash stored in safes is now fully covered under our property insurance policy, up to USD 15,000, which is sufficient for almost all our stores.

Namely, there are several operational roadblocks help mitigate this risk such as:

• New stores cannot commence operations without proof of insurance, which is mandatory for all malls regionwide.
• Minor works clearance is not given by any mall without proof of any valid certificate.
• Regulatory requirements by governing bodies require proof of insurance
• Joint Ventures require proof of insurance for warehouses and rented premises, etc...

Nevertheless, we fully recognize the importance of having clear, documented procedures to improve efficiency and accountability. 

Service Request and Incident Management Portal will be created for requests related to insurance related service requests and incident management following loss. This will help to:

• Streamline processes for incident reporting and claims management.

Absence of Money Insurance coverage across the Group

The Group currently lacks an insurance policy to cover risks associated with the loss of money during transit, on-premises, or in safes due to any unforeseen events. This exposes the company to potential financial losses in scenarios where cash is targeted.
It is pertinent to note that there is a third party cash collection and deposit service provider that covers the risk of cash in transit while in their custody for up to 500K USD for store locations in UAE, KSA, Kuwait, Bahrain and Qatar. India also uses a third party collection service. 
However, this control is not present in Jordan, Oman and Egypt Duty free shops and excludes cash maintained in office safes.
